title: EmonTX shield & Yun enclosure (Power Monitor Box)

description.text:
This is the first version of the enclosure I created for EmonTX shield and Arduino Yun boards.
EmonTX shield is a board from openenergymonitor.org that can be used with an Arduino, to measure the Power Consumption at home. This version is based on the grate work of "Arduino OpenSCAD mounting library (v2.0)", by kellyegan. The box has 2 lids. The top lid -that is sealing the box- and the CTs lid. This lid was needed, since the board have a lot of components like USBs, Power, CTs in the different faces of the box.
Mounting Instructions

First you put in place the Arduino Yun and screw on the box.
Then you attach the CTs lid on the EmonTX shield and then you put the shield on top of Arduino.
The top lid has a window in order to be able to see the led of the board when is blinking. There is a window printed part that you can print with transparent filament and put in place.
At the end close the box with the top lid. Included files:
EmonTX-box.stl - is the enclosure
EmonTX-CTs_lid.stl - is the CTs lid
EmonTX-box_lid.stl - is the top lid
EmonTX-lid_led.stl - is the "window" of the top lid I am still working on some fixes.
In the next version, the openscad files will be also provided.

author: xerox1821

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:279864 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=279864
A fully functional fork, based on scans of a stainless steel Wiltshire fork. Comes complete with a cheeky Makerbot logo. Just print and eat!

Prints within the build envelope of a Thing-o-Matic with ABP, although I suggest switching off "Outline" in your Skeinforge profile to avoid the Y axis hitting the endstop at the start of the build. Use a platform temp of 125C to prevent curling.
For those who are curious, I took a photo of the real fork, traced it in Inkscape to vectorise it and then dropped it into blender for scaling before exporting as STL.

comments.text: we ran out of forks at the store. you have saved me.

remixed_from.author: MarkBenson
remixed_from.title: Dual i3 Bowden JHead Hotend Mount

title: E3D Dual Bowden Fed Hotend Mount for Prusa i3

description.text: Mounts to Prusa i3 x carriage with 2 M3x30 screws. 3 More M3x30 screws/nuts/washers clamp the set together. The mounting holes are 24mm apart. The nozzles are 26mm apart. Fan duct mounts a single 40mm fan to cool both barrels. EDIT: I made the "clamp" piece thicker because mine cracked when it was fully tight. This could have been an artifact of my 0.6mm nozzle not perfectly forming the grooves. The zip file has the original version.

Print out one of each piece. Press fit 3 M3 nuts into the 3 nut traps on the back of the "mount" piece. Attach the "mount" to the x carriage using M3 screws&nuts of appropriate length. Slide the dual fan duct over the top of the hotends. It should rest slightly on the heat sink of the hotend. Mount the hot ends and use the "clamp" piece and three screws with washers to clamp the hot ends to the mount. Attach your bowden connectors/lines and you're ready to go.

Both files have interlocking shapes like a puzzle, put glue on the end of one and put together to dry.
Enjoy!

Created by the union of 2 voronoi meshes, one with small lattice and one with large lattice+edges. Software used:
K3Dsurf to generate gyroid mesh
Meshlab to apply voronoi filters and add volume
Blender to create union of 2 voronoi meshes
Back to meshlab for smoothing and resampling
Netfabb cloud for cleanup 3/29/14 added a reduced poly count mesh model

comments.text: It's not good to scan with the digitizer facing an open window like that.  Try pointing it at a dark wall.  Also might need to coat that statue with something to give it a more matt gray finish so the lasers can pick it up better.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Thank you for the advice.  It's not my model, so I can't coat it.  I also had the door only open to let light in for the normal photo.  It's interesting that it did not "see" the hollow base at all.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: You could try multi scan with it sitting in different positions like on it's side, that might help get more of the hollow inside.

Monterey Bay is located on the Central Coast of California, south of San Francisco. There is a large underwater canyon located just off shore and this model is meant to represent that. Due to the large area there is a vertical exaggeration of 3 for this model. High Elevation: 1470m
Low Elevation: -3700m
Area: 24,331 km2

This model was generated using a program that is currently being developed. It is based on the GMRT dataset (http://www.marine-geo.org/portals/gmrt/) and utilized the interface from GeoMapApp (http://www.geomapapp.org)
You may reduce the problem about the model curling on Replicator.

Radial Post.  I have included the inventor files for your use in modification or customization.

This is a design for a desk vice that could be printed with a makerbot, obvioulsy this would not be as solid a normal metal desk vice, however it should still be strong enough for many light jobs.
The vice head could be shod with metal (using a couple of metal strips and a few drops of glue) to improve the usefulness of the tool.
I designed it around a long metal bolt I have in my junk draw, but the design could be modified to use a commodity bolt available at a hardware store or preferably a printable threaded bolt (still trying to figure out how to make threads in Sketchup - any advice on this would be appreciated).

This design is untested The two main vice halves fit together as shown in the diagram, the crank fits on the end of the bolt which then goes through the first vice half (where a loose fitting nut is placed on the bolt with some loctite to hold it in place. (NOTE the printed halves have no thread in their hold and the bolt is meant to free spin in them when first inserted). A single nut is glued to the second half inside the slot provided to act as a thread to push and pull the second half of the vice. Finally the crank is attached to the head of the bolt. 3 STLs + the SKP Plate 1 = The first half of the vice
Plate 2 = The Second half of the vice
Plate 3 = The crank in two pieces

description.text:
I had a broken battery cover for my Subaru remote transmitter. I created a "standard" replacement and an "optional" replacement. I prefer the "optional" version as the stock version seems to have a weak point where the key ring attaches. Replacement cover for Subaru part number: 88035AC231 UPDATE 1/31/15:
My remote stopped working after I dropped my keys. I traced the problem back to a weak battery retaining tab on my cover. So I've increased the retaining tab wall thickness from 1 mm to 1.5 mm. All files have been updated. It should fit the following vehicles:
2004 Subaru Forester
2004 Subaru Impreza
2004 Subaru Legacy
2004 Subaru Outback
2003 Subaru Forester
2003 Subaru Impreza
2003 Subaru Legacy
2003 Subaru Outback
2002 Subaru Forester
2002 Subaru Impreza
2002 Subaru Legacy
2002 Subaru Outback
2001 Subaru Forester
2001 Subaru Impreza
2001 Subaru Legacy
2001 Subaru Outback
I printed mine at 100% fill with 0.15 mm layers.

comments.text: Could you possibly model up the fron side to?
comments.author: XThatcrazyhoboX

comments.text: Sorry, I no longer have that car/remote in order to develop the CAD files.
comments.author: XThatcrazyhoboX

comments.text: Also works for a 99 Legacy
comments.author: parametricbuild

description.text:
Replacement valves and heads for the Haynes model engine.
Printed on a makerbot replicator
I found the best results printing with no raft and with 100%  infill.

comments.text: Hey, i have this exact same model engine but unfortunately the timing belt is very lose. would you be able to design a part to fix this problem? Thanks in advance.
